Before the reforms, the Lord Chancellor had both executive and judicial powers, which raised concerns about potential conflicts of interest and a lack of separation between the judiciary and the executive branches of government. This led to criticism that the Lord Chancellor was too powerful, with too much responsibility and too little accountability.  

By separating the judicial and executive responsibilities, the reform ensured greater independence of the judiciary and a more modern and efficient administration of justice. The creation of the Ministry of Justice allowed for a more centralized approach to the administration of the courts, which ultimately led to a more streamlined and effective system. 

While there may be debate about the effectiveness of the reforms, it is generally agreed that the changes helped to strengthen the independence of the judiciary, protect the rule of law, and modernize the UK justice system.
